title: $A falls after Chinese equities meltdown
text:
Tue, Jul 28, 2015, 7:54 AM AEST - Australia Markets open in 2 hrs 6 mins $A falls after Chinese equities meltdown AAP â€“ 38 minutes ago Print 
The Australian dollar is weaker following an aggressive sell-off in Chinese equities. 
At 0700 AEST on Tuesday, the currency was trading at 72.69 US cents, down from 72.79 cents on Monday. 
China will unleash more funds to stabilise its jittery share market, after Shanghai stocks posted their biggest daily fall for more than eight years. 
BK Asset Management managing director of FX strategy Boris Schlossberg said the Aussie was also still suffering from commodity price drops. 
The full ramifications of China's slowdown will start to be felt in the second half of the year, he said. 
"A lot of the capital projects that have been delayed in the mining sector are very likely to be scrapped altogether," he said. 
Mr Schlossberg said there'd soon be a very negative cycle of contraction that probably would be felt across most of the Australian economy. 
"It's (the economy is) still so heavily dependent on the mining sector for growth that right now very few analysts expect Australia to escape a recession unscathed," he said. 
CURRENCY SNAPSHOT AT 0700 AEST ON TUESDAY 
One Australian dollar buys: 
* 72.69 US cents, from 72.79 cents on Monday 
* 89.59 Japanese yen, from 89.82 yen 
* 65.57 euro cents, from 66.01 euro cents 
* 110.08 New Zealand cents, from 110.27 NZ cents 
* 46.73 British pence, from 46.90 pence 
(*Currency closes taken at 1700 AEST previous local session) 
Source: IRESS
